qas.question: According to the functional interpretation, what principle is opposite of the rule of man?
What level of discretion do governments with a high degree of the "rule of law" have?
What level of discretion do governments with a low degree of the "rule of law" have?
What happens to those that do not follow to the rule of law?
What fights against the rule of law?
What does a Society have a high degree of if its government officers have a great deal of discretion?
What does a society have a low degree of if its government officials have little disctetion?
What is necessary for offenses that are justifiable unter statutory law but not natural law?

context: The functional interpretation of the term "rule of law", consistent with the traditional English meaning, contrasts the "<a0_0>rule of law<a0_0/>" with the "rule of man." According to the functional view, a society in which government officers have <a2_0>a great deal<a2_0/> of discretion has a low degree of <b5_0><b6_0>"rule of law",<b6_0/><b5_0/> whereas a society in which government officers have <a1_0>little<a1_0/> discretion has a high degree of "rule of law". Upholding the rule of law can sometimes require the <a3_0><b7_0>punishment<b7_0/><a3_0/> of those who commit offenses that are justifiable under natural law but not statutory law. <b8_0>The rule of law<b8_0/> is thus somewhat at odds with flexibility, even when <a4_0>flexibility<a4_0/> may be preferable.
